title: I received a Substitution of Attorney-civil on a Judgement from 2007.How much time do I have before they can garnish my wages?I
question: It is roughly 18,000.00 now with fees etc.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Wage garnishment,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Default judgment
answers: Depending on the laws in California. they may have to take steps in court before they can garnish wages. In Ohio, for example, a judgment becomes "stale" after 5 years and has to be revived. Short of something like that, there is no way to know when garnishments may begin. Your options would be to contact the creditor's attorney to see if a settlement can be reached or filing a bankruptcy.

There is no way of knowing when they will garnish, but your employer will provide you with a notice when they do.

Chapter 7 sounds like it may be best for you.

BW

Included as an option is contacting the judgment holder's law firm and settling the debt, such that a satisfaction of judgment in full is filed in the case, showing that the judgment has been fully resolved. I have had success in settling old judgments for clients, who wish to avoid bankruptcy.
